stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the session defining the late-game “Ice Castle” course: mapping its physical layout, listing star objectives, brainstorming unique mechanics, and prototyping a workable ice-brick visual style with live shader/combiner tests.

development_findings.summary: Course theme set as a lonely, late-game ice castle evoking Tick Tock Clock difficulty and atmosphere.
development_findings.quote: I want you to think about levels like Tick Tock Clock when you think about this here.

development_findings.summary: Overall layout will be a U/H-shaped multi-storey castle with a bridge linking two towers, a foyer with slippery stairs, a basement ‘cold-haze’ section that damages Mario over time, and an exterior snowfield.

Current star plan: 1) red-coin star outside/courtyard, 2) platforming star visible early via slippery foyer stairs, 3) cold-haze basement traversal, 4) boss fight against a giant Raven on the roof, 5) 8-bit pipe mini-level themed after Mario Land 1, 6) snowman cave reached through a hill beside the castle (still fluid).

New platforming mechanics under consideration: sliding ice waves the player rides, rotating hexagonal ice prisms that redirect wall-jumps, gusts of wind, cracking ice blocks, reflective ice floors, and an ‘appearing path’ Galaxy-style.

Visual R&D: testing two reflection approaches—(a) CPU-generated normal-map reflections per wall direction (limited to six orientations, expensive) and (b) simpler scrolling additive shine texture; IA8 format chosen over RGBA16 to reduce N64 color-quantisation artefacts.
development_findings.quote: The format we used there was RGBA16… quantisation looks a lot less bad because now it's four-bit alpha instead of one.

development_findings.summary: Zeina’s ‘icy bricks combiner’ material is the current base; Kaze tweaked combiner settings and camera-dependent texture scrolling for a frosty shine effect.
Technical groundwork: Kaze wrote a custom N64 OS (rewrite of Libultra) for finer control and future optimisation.
development_findings.quote: I wrote a new OS for my N64… it gives me a lot more control.

development_findings.summary: Plans to exploit frame-buffer tricks: rooms where the buffer isn’t cleared to create busy echoing visuals; potential use of fake volumetric fog similar to PC-port experiments.
Ambition to launch the game simultaneously on real N64 hardware and PC for ‘insane advertising’.
development_findings.quote: Dual release on PC and N64 at the same time is perfectly possible.

development_findings.summary: Source code will be released publicly, continuing Kaze’s open-source practice.
development_findings.quote: Despite what people seem to think I will release the source code.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows playful frustration at Twitch bot raids, haircut mishap, and texture-quantisation issues; overall tone remains upbeat and iterative.
Expresses philosophy of open development: frequent source releases and desire for simultaneous multi-platform launch.
Mentions writing the new OS as a personal optimisation challenge.

biobak.summary: Worked off-stream with Kaze to explore art styles; provided the initial icy-brick texture that outperformed Kaze’s tests in-stream.
biobak.quote: He had some neat ideas and I had some neat ideas… I think this is a decent art style for this level.

zeina.summary: Provided the ‘icy bricks combiner’ material Kaze used as the shader base.
Currently modelling/animating the giant Raven boss.
zeina.quote: Oh, Zeina's making the raven. That looks pretty nice.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Ice-Brick Look
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak experiment live with textures and combiners to find a believable ice-brick shader that survives N64 colour limits.
key_stories.challenge: RGBA16 quantisation produced ugly banding and purple artefacts.
key_stories.process: Switched to IA8 palettes, adjusted combiner math, introduced camera-scroll shine, compared with Biobak’s version.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on a frosty scrolling-shine material based on Zeina’s combiner; CPU-normal-map method kept as future possibility.
key_stories.key_quote: Why does Biobak picking a random blue texture just look better than me actually… is this not just combiner?

key_stories.title: Writing a New N64 Operating System
key_stories.summary: Off-stream, Kaze rewrote large parts of Libultra to streamline performance for Return to Yoshi’s Island.
key_stories.challenge: Libultra’s overhead and lack of flexibility for modern tricks.
key_stories.process: Stripped Libultra to essentials, rebuilt modules for tighter control, plans ongoing optimisation.
key_stories.outcome: Already running; expected to unlock significant optimisation opportunities for the hack.
key_stories.key_quote: It's basically just a rewrite of Libultra… we're gonna find a lot of optimisations with the new OS.

open_questions.topic: Performance cost of CPU-generated normal-map reflections
open_questions.context: Kaze notes it is expensive and limited to six wall orientations but doesn’t quantify the hit or decide if it will ship.
questions: What framerate penalty does the normal-map method impose on real N64 hardware?
Have you profiled it against the simpler scrolling-shine approach?
Will you keep it only for showcase rooms or drop it entirely?

open_questions.context: Only five stars are fully locked; one remains undecided and overall progression order is still rough.

open_questions.context: Kaze claims the rewrite is done and yields more control.
